newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian truck owners back at work after strike.
newsitem.headline: Indian truck owners back at work after strike.

text.p: Indian truck owners returned to work on Thursday after a 10-day strike that crippled industry and pushed up prices, but they said freight rates would rise before a backlog in goods was cleared in two weeks' time.
"It will take 15 days for goods piled up to be cleared," S.P. Singh, spokesman of the All-India Motor Transport Congress (AIMTC), told Reuters.
"The freight rate will go up by 15 to 20 percent during this period... The rates will normalise after that," another AIMTC official added.

Truck owners on Wednesday ended the strike after the government agreed to their demand that they not be held responsible for collecting a five percent service tax and to hold a proposed rise in insurance premiums in abeyance.
The AIMTC, which represents nearly 2.2 million truck owners, said the strike had been called off in all states including western Maharashtra where it had continued well into Thursday.
"The strike has ended in Maharashtra also," Chittaranjan Dass, AIMTC president, told Reuters.

News agencies quoted Maharashtra Chief Minister Manohar Joshi as saying that members of the state truckers' union went back to work after a meeting with the government at which both sides reached agreement on most of the truckers' demands.
Singh said truck owners had lost about 36 billion rupees ($1 billion) due to the strike. Analysts said the economy faced an estimated loss of about 70 to 80 billion rupees a day.
"By today evening about 450,000 trucks will be on the roads," Singh said. It would be two to three days before all trucks took to the roads as most drivers had gone on leave.

"Fruit and vegetable prices have gone up by at least 25 percent in different states," said an official of the Punjab, Haryana and Delhi Chambers of Commerce and Industry. "But it will normalise soon."
He said industrial production in the northern states had come to a "grinding halt" and estimated it would take two days to restart.
"We are still working out the loss (to industry)," he said.
Analysts said the arrivals at market of summer crops of rice, wheat and oilseed had come to a standstill.
Shipping had also been hit. "I expect a lot of export commitments to be cancelled," said one Bombay-based commodity analyst. ($1 = 35.8 rupees)
